transcripts.text: Ski ball is my life.  I met my wife playing ski ball.  Ski ball has had a material impact on my life and I want to share that with others and this space will be a conduit for that.
Joey Mucha is a three-time skee-ball national champion and the owner of Joey the Cat, an arcade rental repair and events company that he started in 2010.

Building my business started out as a side project to my day job.  I bought that skee-ball machine on eBay to practice and then had to learn how to repair it.  So the natural progression was to put it in a bar, see if it could make some recurring revenue, and then use that money to buy another skee-ball machine.

In 2014, Mucha purchased this warehouse in San Francisco's Mission District as a repair and storage facility.  In 2019, he decided to convert it into an arcade and restaurant, which should have been a straightforward process since the property was already zoned for commercial use.  But a community activist incurring nothing more than a $600 fee was able to temporarily scuttle Mucha's plans, forcing him to spend months rallying community support and pleading his case at a public hearing.  Joey the Cat's new outpost is slated to open in spring of 2021, but the story of how the project was nearly stopped and what Mucha endured in order to prevail underscores how even the most benign land use changes in San Francisco can be hampered by red tape.  It's a root cause of the city's housing crisis and jeopardizes San Francisco's competitiveness over the long term.
Joey the Cat should be renamed Joey the Liar.
This is within 500 feet of an elementary school.  We're talking about proximity to schools.  We don't need our young people walking by that and seeing these negative toxic images.

I'm not converting this to a private event space only for corporates.  I'm converting this to a public space that can be used by all.  In a perfect world, if there was no red tape, we would have been open six months ago.

Mucha's troubles started when Kevin Ortiz, a local activist affiliated with the anti-gentrification group Cultural Action Network, filed an application for discretionary review, a process through which any member of the public can ask the San Francisco Planning Commission to review an application for a building permit.  Neither Ortiz nor Cultural Action Network responded to our interview request.  Even though these reviews are supposed to be used only under exceptional and extraordinary circumstances, they've become a regular part of the city's land use process.  For example, the owner of a falafel restaurant was able to delay the opening of a competitor by claiming that the neighborhood already had enough falafel.  This home's third floor addition was blocked on the grounds that it wasn't sufficiently Victorian.  The conversion of a laundromat to an apartment building has been delayed for over five years due in part to its casting a shadow on an already shaded schoolyard.  So far in 2019, the Planning Commission publicly heard 91 requests for discretionary review.  Because every building permit in the city is subject to this process, it adds enormous costs to construction, exacerbating the city's severe housing shortage.  Mucha prevailed by devoting enormous time to winning over community support, which otherwise would have gone into running his business.

I've basically become a politician, which I don't want to become and I don't want that for anyone.  I've watched a bunch of planning commission hearings and research to kind of understand the concept because small business owners shouldn't be flung into this process and and expected to be perfect at this when the activists are going to these almost weekly.  I've gotten a profile on all the different planning commissioners.  I know their names and I know kind of what they vote for and against.  My team and I went and garnered as much support as we could from the community.  And we've worked with architects and had to figure out how to make this space work for both what I want it to be and what is legally permitted and make good business sense out of it.  And finding that triangulation is incredibly complex and challenging and has been a very burdensome process for a small business owner.
Muta went door to door in the Mission asking for help from his neighbors.  At the hearing, more than twice as many supporters as opponents came out to speak.
Joy the Cat is fun for both adults and children, and more importantly, it is kept clean and it is a safe environment, which is more than I can say for some of the parks in our neighborhood.
political connections also came into play.  Mutra received a letter of support from California State Treasurer Fiona Ma, who once held a fundraiser at Joey's Arcade.

On a principal level, I think it's so hard for a small business owner to be successful in this city.  And when you start to layer on red tape or these hurdles and roadblocks that come out of personal interests or community interests that don't necessarily align with the business, it makes it very difficult.  And I think it's something that should be changed at a policy level.
